intro: Diplostephium tachirense, commonly known as the Tachira false dandelion, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly Venezuela and Colombia. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats and has a rosette of basal leaves with a hairy surface. Its yellow flowers are arranged in a flat head, and the plant produces small, oval fruits called cypsela. It is often used in traditional medicine for its purported anti-inflammatory properties.
